awd_titl_txt: Exhibit appraisal and diverse populations: Pilot research about intersectional and science identities in science exhibits
awd_abstract_narration:
As part of its overall strategy to enhance learning in informal environments, the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program funds innovative research, approaches, and resources for use in a variety of settings. This project will explore how understanding visitors' experiences with science museum exhibits may contribute to increasing engagement among diverse audiences. Museums have made great strides in understanding how exhibit design can support underrepresented audiences, but often tend to focus on individual demographic groups such as females, certain racial and ethnic minorities, and people with disabilities. This project will explore relationships between visitors' demographic and science identities to assess the affordances of using science identity as an intersectional proxy that could help the field move beyond its reliance on demographics. Building on prior National Science-funded work about museum engagement, the project applies appraisal theory--a psychological model about how people make conscious and subconscious assessments of situations that manifest in emotions--to the informal learning context. To date, museums have tended to focus on cognitive and behavioral aspects of engagement. Appraisal theory can add emotional processes to the conceptual understanding of engagement, and can be applied to help exhibit professionals develop a design framework that upholds complex identities. Such a framework could have implications for inclusive design of learning experiences in museums, schools, and other educational contexts.

This Pilot and Feasibility Study will address methodological and theoretical questions about the feasibility of a research approach that considers the relationships among: 1) exhibit design features; 2) multiple identity factors including science identity, demographics, and self-defined personal identity; 3) visitor appraisals; and 4) engagement with exhibits. Led by researchers at the Museum of Science, Boston and EdTogether, a non-profit research and development organization for inclusive design, the project will begin with a pre-piloting phase during which researchers will work with youth and professional advisors from local community organizations to test a suite of data collection approaches including self-report in the form of questionnaires and interviews; observations of visitor engagement; and biometric data collection including galvanic skin response and eye tracking. Building from this pre-piloting phase, the team will conduct four mini-studies that will iteratively refine measures towards enhanced validity and parsimony while gathering data to test the investigators' hypothesized model of design, identity, appraisal, and engagement. The evidence from testing this model through the four mini-studies will lay the foundation for larger-scale research that intends to explore causal relationships among intersectional identities, science identities, appraisal, and visitor engagement.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Exhibit appraisal and diverse populations: Pilot research about intersectional and science identities in science exhibits (APPRAISE) was led by the Museum of Science, Boston with collaborators from EdTogether and Children's Museum of Pittsburgh. The project team worked extensively with minoritized youth between the ages of 9 and 17, including youth of color, girls and non-binary youth, and youth with disabilities, to create a research protocol that can: 

  • Complexify our understandings of youth identity

  • Support youth metacognition about their identities and appraisals of museum exhibits

  • Provide a scaffolded approach for youth to have conversations with museum professionals that inform exhibit design

The APPRAISE team created the research protocol through four iterative rounds of testing. These rounds of testing allowed us to explore how to collect data about youths' identities, including their demographics, science identities, and other interests; their appraisals, or emotional responses, to exhibit components; outcomes for the youth after using the exhibit components; and how all of these intersect with exhibit components' design, including their activity formats, content, and physical elements. In total, over 100 youth participated in the project including 99 research subjects between the ages of 9 and 17 and over 20 youth interns, staff, and paid youth advisors who helped with data collection, analysis, and protocol development. 

Data for the study were collected at both the Museum of Science, Boston and Children's Museum of Pittsburgh. Findings from the research show that there were no demographic differences between youth with high and low science identities in our study indicating that exhibit design should focus on nurturing science identity regardless of youths' demographics. Additionally, we found that when youth talk about their identities and how they influence their decision making about using exhibits they typically talked about their interests, personalities, and activities that they participate in. While they rarely discussed demographic factors such as race, gender, and ability, when these topics did come up, youth were able to discuss these aspects of identity in ways that helped illuminate potentially exclusionary exhibit design.

When youth talked about what made an exhibit be "for them," they often focused on the component's activity format. In particular, youth appeared to be attracted to exhibit components that were more active such as those where they could do things as opposed to components that were more passive and focused on things like reading. The same content could make an exhibit feel like it was both "for" and "not for" different youth. Other aspects of an exhibit such as its look and feel did not seem to have as much impact on whether youth felt an exhibit was for them. 

The APPRAISE team developed our study protocol to understand the intersection between youth identities, appraisals, outcomes, and exhibit design. Through our data collection, we found that the protocol can be useful in scaffolding youth's understandings of their identities, including their science identities, in relationship to how they feel about (or appraise) exhibits and describe outcomes, and that this scaffolding help them to discuss the connections between these concepts and aspects of design. Quantitative findings indicate that appraisals are sensitive to and predicative of youth judgements about whether an exhibit is "for them" as well as their sense of belonging and intent to engage. Qualitative findings indicate meaningful relationships among how youth understand and describe their identities, their appraisals of aspects of exhibit design, and engagement related outcomes. While more research with a greater variety of exhibits is needed to generate further generalizable findings, we feel that the protocol could be used by other science museums to scaffold conversations with youth or other visitors to help museum professionals think more deeply about their exhibit design decisions.
